title: Where's the angst? Blue Bombers are happiest 4-10 football team on the planet |
text:
The music was playing and the mood was light, players grooving to the beat and joking around with teammates like they were on top of the world.
If an alien had been dropped into the middle of the proceedings, it would have thought this was a team on a roll.
Your Winnipeg Blue Bombers — the happiest 4-10 team on the planet, if not in the history of football.
Throw a crushing defeat at them, one in which the league itself admits they were jobbed by the refs, they come right back and say they need to be better – and then they are.
Throw another even more bitter loss at at them a week later, their fate decided by a kicker, they still come out with smiles on their faces and a jive in their steps, content to know they’re still not out of it.
“I’ve been part of teams in my career ... when things go bad like this you’ve got guys starting to turn on each other, you’ve got a lot of finger-pointing,” Bombers D-lineman Bryant Turner was saying, Wednesday. “There’s nothing like that in this locker-room at all.”
In charge of it all, Mr. Happy, head coach Mike O’Shea, who prefers hugs to hard-ass, positive reinforcement to punishment.
Where some coaches in his position would have steam coming out of their ears as they crack the whip at practice, O’Shea prefers to wear a grin with his track suit, day after day, even as his team’s record plummets.
“He’s a weird character in that sense,” Turner said. “Because he can be smiling at you and be p—d off. He can easily give you a smile and it’s a kick in the butt. He’s not going to blow his head and jump all over you.”
Turner says that approach doesn’t work with grown men, anyway. He’s seen coaches try it, only to have it backfire.
At this point a Bomber fan might rightfully point out the obvious. Scream it out, actually: O’SHEA’S APPROACH ISN’T FREAKING WORKING EITHER!
No, it’s not. After starting last season 5-1, the Bombers went 2-10. Combined with this year’s record, they’ve won just six of their last 26 games.
Yet, he hasn’t changed from those early days. He still won’t coach with fear, preferring a verbal caress to a curse, keeping a promise he made to his players from the start.
“If I say get the job done, or get the (curse word) job done, it means the exact same thing,” is what Turner remembers his coach saying. “He let us know that early. So guys understood it exactly. And he’s been that way ever since.”
Even as the losses pile up like four-letter words.
Going into this weekend’s tilt in Vancouver, where his team finally has to win or else kiss its playoff chances goodbye, nothing has changed.
There was O’Shea during stretching exercises, Wednesday, tossing not expletives or even a harsh word, but a football at players to make sure they were alert.
He made sure they were ready to catch it, first.
And how about getting them ready to play desperate football against B.C.?
“I don’t know that you want to play with desperation in mind,” O’Shea said. “You want to have a good understanding that it’s playoff football. We’re approaching this as a must-win game. But I don’t know that leads to desperation.
“Sometimes if you’re desperate you’re losing focus. That’s what that word brings to mind, is maybe a loss of focus and a frantic pace without maybe direction. And we don’t want that.”
No, like every other week, you just want a win.
Or you’ll have three meaningless games to be as happy as you want, while nobody gives a four-letter word.
PAUL FRIESEN
